questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with homocystinuria reports joint pain and muscle weakness. Supplementation with which vitamin is beneficial in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, which requires Vitamin B6 as a cofactor. Supplementing with Vitamin B6 can help reduce homocysteine levels and alleviate symptoms like joint pain and weakness.

Homocystinuria:


Explanation for other options:

Vitamin B12 (Option B) deficiency causes type 2 homocystinuria, but there will be additional symptoms of neurological manifestation due to lack of adenosyl B12 and accumulation of methylmalonic acid.

Vitamin B1 (Option C) Thiamine deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Vitamin B7 (Option D) Biotin deficiency causes hair thinning, alopecia, brittle nails prone to splitting or breaking and neurological manifestations since biotin is required for decarboxylases containing enzymes.

Reference:

  1. Adenosylcobalamin
  2. Methylcobalamin

questions.text: A diabetic patient is recommended to begin an exercise regimen. Which of the following glucose transporters is sensitive to insulin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This GLUT 4 is insulin-sensitive and is primarily found in adipose tissue, cardiac and skeletal muscle. During exercise, insulin facilitates glucose uptake via GLUT4, helping regulate blood glucose levels

GLUT 1-5 are facilitative bidirectional transporters, whereas SGLT 1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is found unconscious after playing with shampoo that contained rotenone. Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rotenone inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia.

Electron Transport Chain:

  • ETC complexes are present in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • There are 5 protein complexes in ETC: Complex I to V

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D) is an uncoupling agent that disrupts the coupling of electron transport and ATP synthesis in mitochondria. If DNP were added, it would uncouple oxidative phosphorylation from respiration but wouldn't block respiration entirely.

questions.text: A patient presents with anaemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair. Which micronutrient deficiency is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anaemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmented skin and hair are seen in copper deficiency.

Explanation for other options:

Zinc (Option A) deficiency presents with poor Wound healing, skin Lesions: Rashes, dermatitis, hyperkeratosis, alopecia, impaired spermatogenesis, decreased T and B lymphocyte counts, impaired macrophage function and Acrodermatitis Enteropathica. It does not present with hypopigmentation.

Fluoride (Option B) deficiency presents with caries and dental problems.

Selenium (Option D) deficiency presents with Keshan disease. It is characterised by multifocal myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac enlargement.

questions.text: A patient has severe abdominal pain and raised lipase levels. Imaging shows a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). Which additional enzyme is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gamma-glutamyl transferase levels are elevated in bile duct obstruction, such as a stone in the common bile duct, along with alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

LDH (Option B) Elevated LDH levels may indicate cell damage or injury in various organs. LDH is a non-specific marker; its levels can be elevated due to various conditions affecting different organs.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482489/

choices.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 1 (VDDR type 1)
Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 2 (VDDR type 2)

questions.text: A child presents with bone deformities. Lab findings show normal serum calcium, normal PTH, low phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterised by low phosphate levels, normal calcium and PTH, and elevated ALP, leading to bone deformities.


Prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism can cause renal osteodystrophy, which may lead to pathological fractures.

Key takeaways:

Vitamin D deficiency presents with:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Elevated parathyroid hormone
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase
  • Decreased 25-hydroxy vitamin D

questions.text: In the given graph, identify the type of inhibition:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme, often resulting in an increased Km without affecting Vmax.

Uncompetitive Inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing it from converting the substrate into a product. This type of inhibition results in:

  • Decrease in Km: Since the inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, it effectively lowers the concentration of the enzyme available for reaction, making the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate appear higher
  • Decrease in Vmax: The inhibitor reduces the maximum rate of reaction because it prevents the enzyme-substrate complex from proceeding to form the product, thus lowering the overall reaction rate at saturating substrate concentrations.

Reference: Physiology, Noncompetitive Inhibitor - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Which combination of metabolites is typically produced in cases of methanol poisoning?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In methanol poisoning, metabolites like formic acid and lactic acid accumulate and cause toxic effects like histotoxic hypoxia and optic neuritis.

  • Methanol poisoning causes the formation of Formate ions. Acids formed lead to defective mitochondria and lactic acidosis, which increase AG. Increase in plasma osmolality. Osmolal gap is also seen.
  • Methanol, also known as wood alcohol, is a CNS depressant often found in illicit liquors. It is highly toxic. Methanol toxicity is infamous for causing metabolic acidosis and optic nerve damage, leading to snowfield vision and potential blindness.

Methanol Poisoning:

Metabolism and Pathophysiology:

  1. Methanol → Formaldehyde (via alcohol dehydrogenase).
  2. Formaldehyde → Formic acid (via aldehyde dehydrogenase).
    • Formic acid leads to:
      • Metabolic acidosis.
      • Retinal damage (optic neuritis).

Symptoms:

  • Early: Severe abdominal cramps.
  • Neurological: Snowfield vision, vision loss, dilated and fixed pupils, muscular weakness.
  • Systemic: CNS and cardiac depression.

Treatment:

    1. Stabilisation: Immediate supportive care.
    2. Haemodialysis: To remove methanol and formic acid.
    3. Antidotes:
      • Ethanol: Competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase.
      • Fomepizole: Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.
    4. Other Therapies:
      • Folinic acid: Enhances formic acid metabolism.
      • Sodium bicarbonate: Treats acidosis.

Glycolic acid and oxalic acid (Option A, C, D) are mainly formed in ethylene glycol poisoning

Postmortem Findings:

  • Putamen haemorrhagic necrosis (specific finding).
  • Absence of postmortem clotting.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase can be caused by a deficiency of dihydrobiopterin reductase (BH2), which helps in the conversion of dihydrobiopterin to tetrahydrobiopterin. This leads to the failure of the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.

Phenylketonuria (PKU)

PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This deficiency leads to an accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, including phenylpyruvic acid.

Mental Retardation:

  • Cause: Mental retardation in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylketones, which compete with other neutral amino acids for transport across the blood-brain barrier.
  • Management: To prevent mental retardation, a phenylalanine-restricted diet should be followed, along with tyrosine supplements.

Hypopigmentation:

  • Cause: Reduced melanin production in PKU results from a deficiency in tyrosine, a crucial component for melanin synthesis. This leads to lighter skin and hair colour compared to individuals without PKU.

Musty/ Mousy urine odour:

  • Cause: Due to the accumulation of phenylpyruvic acid (from excess phenylalanine) in the urine

Non-classic phenylketonuria Type II is characterised by a defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase.

Explanation for other options:

Tyrosine transaminase (Option A) causes Type II tyrosinemia, but does not cause phenylketonuria. Also known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia

Dopa Decarboxylase (Option B) is involved in the conversion of DOPA to Dopamine. It requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.

Tyrosine hydroxylase (Option C) converts Tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), does not cause phenylketonuria

questions.text: A patient presents with dermatitis, dementia, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Clinical scenario of Dermatitis, Dementia and Cognitive decline suggests Niacin deficiency (Pellagra)

Pellagra is characterised by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
  • Bright red erythema in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
  • Casal's necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck (image)

  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia.

Explanation for other options:

Thiamine (Option B) (Vitamin B1) deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Tryptophan (Option C) plays a crucial role in various metabolic processes. It serves as a precursor for Niacin (Vitamin B3) and Serotonin. Thus, symptoms like mood alteration, decreased/increased appetite are also present.

Riboflavin (Option D) deficiency causes cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis and proliferation of bulbar conjunctival capillaries.

Key takeaways:

Signs and symptoms of Pellagra:

  • Dermatitis
  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia
  • Delirium
  • Depression
  • Death

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum-based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
  • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
    1. Vitamin B6 Deficiency
    2. Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
    3. Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
    4. Genetic Disorders: Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome - Excessive tryptophan is utilised for serotonin synthesis, causing niacin deficiency
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    1. Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    2. Malabsorption Syndromes

questions.text: A patient's X-ray shows cardiomegaly, and they present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of cardiomegaly, hypotonia, macroglossia and hepatosplenomegaly are suggestive of Pompe's disease.

Explanation for other options:

Ebstein anomaly (Option B) is associated with atrialisation of the ventricle and a history of lithium exposure in the antenatal period, and it does not present with hypotonia.

Down syndrome (Option C): It does not present with hypotonia after birth

Cori Disease (Option D) involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly.

Reference: Pompe disease diagnosis and management guideline - PMC

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia, macroglossia, and hepatomegaly. Additionally, a patient with elevated triglycerides (esterified with long-chain fatty acids) presents with fatigue, and a muscle biopsy reveals fat vacuoles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carnitine deficiency manifests with fatigue, and muscle biopsy shows fat vacuoles

Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation→hypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation→muscular weakness

Explanation for other options:

Fatty Acid Synthase defect (Option B) causes growth retardation, neurological deficits due to impaired myelination, fatigue or muscle weakness from energy imbalance, impaired wound healing and skin abnormalities due to disrupted lipid synthesis.

Lipoprotein Lipase Deficiency (Option C) causes eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis and recurrent pancreatitis.

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (Option D) cause Hypoketotic hypoglycemia , vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, coma during metabolic crises, hepatomegaly and liver dysfunction due to fatty infiltration and sudden unexplained death.

questions.text: A patient presents with xanthomas on the Achilles tendon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an inherited disorder characterised by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. Xanthomas, which are deposits of cholesterol in the skin or tendons, are a hallmark of this condition.

Tangier disease (Option B) includes enlarged orange-colored tonsils, peripheral neuropathy, hepatosplenomegaly and early-onset cardiovascular disease.

Familial hyperchylomicronemia (Option C) causes eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis and recurrent pancreatitis.

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (Option D) presents with Palmar xanthomas: Pathognomonic feature, and Tuberous xanthomas.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, and serum triglyceride levels are 1500 mg/dL. What is the most likely underlying defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation of severe abdominal pain and elevated serum triglyceride levels suggests familial chylomicronaemia syndrome, and it is caused by an Apo-CII defect.

Explanation for other options:

Apo B-48 defect (Option A) is commonly associated with abetalipoproteinemia. Clinical features include fat malabsorption, Vitamin K deficiency, and Vitamin A deficiency symptoms.

Apo B-100 defect (Option B) (Hypercholesterolemia) presents with atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease (early onset) and Tendon xanthomas.

LDL receptor defect (Option D)(Hypercholesterolemia) presents with atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease (early onset) and Tendon xanthomas.

choices.text: Genetic testing for the TATP7B gene

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with jaundice, fatigue, tremors, muscle rigidity, behavioural changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings. Which of the following investigations is definitive for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of jaundice, fatigue, muscle stiffness, tremors, behavioural changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings(most specific) suggests Wilson's disease, which is diagnosed by serum ceruloplasmin test.

questions.text: A neonate presents with poor feeding and vomiting, cataract, and acidosis with a positive Benedict's test on urine and negative urinary glucose. Which enzyme is likely defective?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency is the most likely cause of the clinical presentation of poor feeding, vomiting, cataracts, acidosis, a positive Benedict's test, and negative urinary glucose as seen in classic Galactosemia; therefore, galactose accumulates.


Explanation for other options:

Aldolase B deficiency Option B) causes essential fructosuria with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, jaundice, potential liver damage and death.

Fructokinase (Option C) deficiency has a low risk of cataracts, as aldose reductase does not act on fructose; also, the symptoms are less severe.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option D) deficiency causes Von Gierke disease; cataract is not a sign in Von Gierke disease.

Key takeaways:

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) deficiency is seen in classic Galactosemia, in which galactose-1-phosphate and therefore galactose accumulate.
